Percentage of streets rated acceptably clean in the CD. Street cleanliness is affected by the rate and amount of littering, the degree of compliance with alternate side parking regulations, and the incidence of Health Administrative Code violations.
Percentage of households that spend 35% or more of their income on rent

The NYCgov poverty rate, which is a poverty measurement specific to New York City. The NYCgov poverty threshold is based on national expenditures on food, clothing, shelter and utilities adjusted for the high cost of housing in New York City. The income side of the measure includes the value of anti-poverty programs such as SNAP, housing assistance, and the earned income tax credit among others as family resources while accounting for medical spending and the costs of commuting and childcare for workers. The NYCgov poverty measure is a historically higher, but more realistic, measure of poverty than the official U.S. measure. That measure does not account for local costs of living, or the value of most anti-poverty benefits.  For more information about the NYCgov Poverty measure see http://www1.nyc.gov/site/opportunity/poverty-in-nyc/poverty-measure.page.
Source: American Community Survey 2014-2018 Public Use Micro Sample, Mayor's Office of Economic Opportunity

The NYCgov poverty rate, which is a poverty measurement specific to New York City, by Public Use Microdata Area (PUMA). PUMAs are geographic approximations of community districts, but their boundaries differ slightly. Some community districts share a PUMA with another district, and will therefore display identical values. The NYCgov poverty threshold is based on national expenditures on food, clothing, shelter and utilities adjusted for the high cost of housing in New York City. The income side of the measure includes the value of anti-poverty programs such as SNAP, housing assistance, and the earned income tax credit among others as family resources while accounting for medical spending and the costs of commuting and childcare for workers. The NYCgov poverty measure is a historically higher, but more realistic, measure of poverty than the official U.S. measure. That measure does not account for local costs of living, or the value of most anti-poverty benefits.  For more information about the NYCgov Poverty measure see http://www1.nyc.gov/site/opportunity/poverty-in-nyc/poverty-measure.page.
Source: American Community Survey 2014-2018 Public Use Micro Sample, Mayor's Office of Economic Opportunity

Description: Percentage of owner-occupied household units considered cost-burdened within the Preliminary Flood Insurance Rate Maps (PFIRM) 1% annual chance floodplain. Owner-occupied households are characterized as cost-burdened if 30% or more of household income is spent on housing costs.

Number of owner-occupied household units with a mortgage within the 2050s 1% annual chance floodplain*. Mortgage refers to all forms of debt where the property is pledged as security for repayment of the debt. Mortgage status is an important determinant in the floodplain as any property with a federally-insured mortgage must carry a federal flood insurance policy.

*Note on future floodplain determination: The 2050s 1% annual chance floodplain projections are derived from the New York City Panel on Climate Change (NPCC) 90th percentile projections for Sea Level Rise.
